quoteFirst: Mr. Balfour did sit in the end. I remember he came to my room about 12.15 p.m. He was sound asleep by
quoteLast: , but woke up sharp at 1 p.m., and left for lunch. What a head! It put all other heads out of the running.
title: An Onlooker in France 1917-1919
author: Orpen, William, Sir, 1878-1931

quoteLast: the island then being in sight, the mast-head look-out sighted a cruiser and three destroyers steaming towards it from the west, and almost immediately afterwards sighted destroyer ’No. 1’ leaving the island.
title: Mr. Midshipman Glover, R.N.: A Tale of the Royal Navy of To-day
author: Jeans, T. T. (Thomas Tendron); Hodgson, E. S. (Edward Smith), 1866-1937 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: The day is filled with duties. From the return of the Battalion from breakfast until 8:00 A.M., is a study period. From 8:00 A.M. until
quoteLast: , the different classes attend recitations in the prescribed courses, or perhaps have instruction in gymnastic exercises or in riding. Dinner comes at 12:40 P.M., after which recitations are held until 3:50 P.M. In the fall and spring drills commence at 4:00 P.M., followed by parade at 5:30 P.M., and retreat and supper at 6:30 P.M.
title:
West Point
An Intimate Picture of the National Military Academy and of the Life of the Cadet
author: Richardson, Robert C. (Robert Charlwood), 1882-1954; Scott, Hugh Lenox, 1853-1934 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteLast: on the 25th the attack started, and in spite of the wire, in some places intact, the first objective was secured. At 1.30 the advance to the second objective began.
title: The Grenadier Guards in the Great War of 1914-1918, Vol. 2 of 3
author: Ponsonby, Frederick, 1867-1935

quoteFirst: 25 there was a stronger wave motion, and that from 8.32 to 8.35 the recording pen was carried off the paper. The vibrations did not entirely cease until
quoteLast: , during this period there having been nearly half an inch of to and fro motion in the surface of the earth.
title: The San Francisco Calamity by Earthquake and Fire
author: Morris, Charles, 1833-1922

quoteLast: the attack was launched, and immediately the creeping barrage was put down by our artillery with great accuracy 200 yards in front of the attacking force. The necessity of getting men across No Man’s Land as promptly as possible after zero had been found from experience to be of paramount importance, and the Grenadier and Irish Guards therefore did not hesitate for a moment, but dashed forward in two waves.
title: The Grenadier Guards in the Great War of 1914-1918, Vol. 2 of 3
author: Ponsonby, Frederick, 1867-1935

title: Warren Commission (09 of 26): Hearings Vol. IX (of 15)
author: United States. Warren Commission

quoteFirst: Crossing one of the sand ridges, got a sight of a range of low sandstone hills to the south-east, the highest of which I named Mount Mueller, as the doctor had seen them the previous evening while collecting plants on one of the sandy ridges near the camp. At 10.15 again made the creek, which had scarcely any channel to mark its course; the wide clay flat bearing marks of former inundations was the only indication visible. At
title: Journals of Australian Explorations
author: Gregory, Augustus Charles, 1819-1905; Gregory, Francis Thomas, 1821-1888

quoteFirst: The greater part of the forenoon was spent in collecting the horses. We left Camp 57 at
quoteLast: When we had proceeded up the western bank of the creek (the side on which we had encamped) for about three-quarters of a mile we crossed it and left it as it became evident that its sources were in the hills to the right of the course we wanted to pursue. After proceeding about six and a quarter miles from the creek in an easterly course over low undulating ridges we saw two emus, which remained in our vicinity for some time but not sufficiently near to induce any of us to try and shoot them.
title: Journal of Landsborough's expedition from Carpentaria, in search of Burke & Wills
author: Landsborough, William, 1825-1886

quoteLast: on September 26, and follow the 54th Brigade upon the left.  The advance was carried out by the 12th Middlesex, with instructions to attack the village, and by the 11th Royal Fusiliers, whose task was to clear the maze of trenches and dug-outs upon the west of the village, while the 6th Northamptons were to be in close support.
title: The British Campaign in France and Flanders, 1916
author: Doyle, Arthur Conan, 1859-1930
